Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the mother needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Story:
I was still in my subway uniform, my mind half on the day’s schedule, when I saw my son’s guilty face at the store. The manager stood beside him, holding a half-opened bag of chips. My heart dropped. As a mother, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to show him that stealing was unacceptable, no matter how small the item. I could see the fear in his eyes, and I wanted to comfort him, to guide him through this mistake with patience and firmness.

But then, my phone buzzed urgently. The subway control center: a brake system malfunction on my train, the one I was scheduled to operate in less than an hour. Protocol demanded I report immediately, ensure passenger safety, and possibly delay the line. My mind raced—my duty as a subway operator was clear and non-negotiable. Hundreds of commuters depended on me to keep them safe and on time.

I stood there, torn between the trembling hand of my son and the flashing alert on my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
